tsn: go nnile le katlego e e bonalang ka go matlafatsa balemi ba basadi ka fa tlase ga togamaano e e malalaotswe go phitlhelelo ya lefatshe (plas).

eng: in a number of provinces, women who have been allocated farms by the dalrrd have been able to run them successfully and even move into commercial production.
tsn: go palo ya diporofense, basadi bao ba neng ba neetswe dipolase ke dlrd ba kgonne go di tsamaisa ka katlego le go fetela kwa tlhagisong ya kgwebo.

eng: in addition to the land acquisition itself, the department continues to invest in infrastructure, equipment and machinery to enable these entrepreneurs to run successful businesses.
tsn: mo godimo ga go bona lefatshe, lefapha le tswelela go beeletsa go ma faratlhatlha, didiriswa le metšhini go kgontsha bagwebi bano go tsamaisa dikgwebo tse di atlegileng.

eng: broadening access to land and opportunities for farming will support job creation and enterprise development, and improve the market for food, agricultural goods and services.
tsn: go oketsa phitlhelelo ya lefatshe le ditšhono tsa go lema go tla tshegetsa go tlhamiwa ga ditiro ka go godisa losika le le ntšhwa la balemi le tlhabololo ya kgwebo, le go tokafatsa mmaraka wa dijo, dithoto tsa temothuo le ditirelo.

eng: the ultimate goal of releasing these land parcels is to transform the agricultural landscape by growing a new generation of farmers.
tsn: maikaelelo a a botlhokwa a go golola diphasele tseno tsa lefatshe ke go fetola selebego sa temothuo ka go godisa losika le le ntšhwa la balemi.

eng: leasing land under such favourable conditions must spur them to think big; to not just grow their own businesses but to advance shared wealth and prosperity in the communities in which they farm.
tsn: go hirisa lefatshe ka fa tlase ga maemo a a siameng jaana go tshwanetse go ba thusa go nagana; eseng fela go godisa dikgwebo tsa bona fela go tsweledisa khumo e e arole lwanang le katlego go baagi bao ba lemang gona.

eng: how to prevent teenage pregnancy vukuzenzele unnamed there are various ways to prevent teenage pregnancy, including choosing not to have sex until you are married or ready to have children.
tsn: ditsela tsa go thibela go nna mo mmeleng ga bašwa vukuzenzele unnamed go na le ditsela tse di farologaneng tse o ka thibelang ka tsona go iphi tlhele o le mo mmeleng e se ka maikaelelo, mme tsona di tsenyeletsa le go se robalane go fitlha o tsena mo kgolaganong ya lenyalo kgotsa go fitlha o ipona gore o siametse go ka nna le bana.

eng: some people think that abstinence (choosing to not have sex until you are married) is oldfashioned, while others think it is morally the best thing to do.
tsn: go na le batho ba ba akanyang gore go itima phate ke selo seo se neng se diriwa bogologolo, mme ba bangwe bona ba akanya gore selo seo ke sona se se botoka thata.

eng: teenagers, however, need to decide for themselves.
tsn: le fa go le jalo, bašwa ke bona ba ba tshwanetseng go itlhophela seo ba bonang se ba siametse mo botshelong.

eng: many people do not want to wait until they are married before having sex.
tsn: batho ba bantsi ga ba batle go letela lenyalo pele ba ka simolola tsa thobalano.

eng: they also do not want to rush into anything and make costly mistakes.
tsn: e bile gape ga ba batle go sianela dilo tseo ka tsona ba tla iphitlhelang di ba weditse mo mogobeng wa mathata a a seng kana ka sepe.

eng: they often decide that delaying having sex until they are older, more responsible, in a stable relationship with one partner and have a job, is the best thing to do.
tsn: go le gantsi ba tsaya tshwetso ya gore selo se se ba siametseng go gaisa ke go se sianele tsa thobalano go fitlha ba ipona gore jaanong ba godile, ba na le maikarabelo, ba ka fa gare ga kgolagano ya lorato e e lolameng moo ba golaganeng le mokapelo a le mongwe fela e bile ba setse ba iponetse le tiro.

eng: if you choose abstinence or delaying sex, there are other things you can do to protect yourself: choose your friends care fully.
tsn: fa e le gore o tsaya tshwetso ya go itima phate kgotsa ya go tsena mo thobalanong, go na le dilo dingwe tse o ka di dirang gore o ipabalele: tlhopha ka kelotlhoko ba tho ba o tsalanang le bona.

eng: friends should want what is best for you and should respect your decision not to have sex.
tsn: ditsala tsa mmatota di go ratela tsotlhe tse di molemo e bile di tlhompha tshwetso ya gago ya go itima phate.

eng: beware of situations that could be unsafe, like friends drinking or taking drugs, that could lead to unsafe sex.
tsn: ela tlhoko maemo a a ka go bayang mo kotsing, a a jaaka ditsala fa di sela bojalwa kgotsa di dirisa diritibatsi, e leng seo se ka dirang gore o iphitlhele o tsene mo thobalanong e e sa babalesegang.

eng: beware of partners who claim that you will sleep with them if you love them.
tsn: itlhokomele mo mookapelong yo a go rayang a re fa tota e le gore o a morata o tla mo naya dikobo.

eng: listen to and learn from those who have gone through teenage pregnancy.
tsn: reetsa le go ithuta mo bathong ba ba kileng ba nna mo mmeleng e santse e le bašwa.

eng: they know the mistakes and disadvantages.
tsn: ba itse sentle diphoso tsa seo le go tlhaloganya ditlamorago tsa teng.

eng: listen to and learn from your parents about their life experiences.
tsn: reetsa le go ithuta mo dikgang tseo batsadi ba gago ba go tlotlelang tsone ka maitemogelo a bona mo botshelong.

eng: if you decide that abstinence and delaying sex are not the best decisions for you and you would rather not wait, take the time to learn about protection, including contraception, which is using a method (mechanical or chemical) to prevent pregnancy.
tsn: fa e le gore wena o bona e le gore go itima phate le go tsaya nako pele o ka tsenela tsa thobalano ga se seo o se batlang, e bile ga o na nako ya go leta, netefatsa gore o tsaya nakonyana o ithute ka tsa go ipabalela mo thobalanong, go tsenyeletsa le dikgato tsa thibelapelegi, di ka tswa e le tsa go dirisa mesomelwana kgotsa go nwa melemo go thibela go nna mo mmeleng.

eng: there are various contraceptives that work in different ways, but they are all designed to prevent pregnancy.
tsn: go na le dithibelapelegi tse di dirang ka ditsela tse di farologaneng, fela tsone tsotlhe di diretswe go thibela go nna mo mmeleng.

eng: they include oral contraception, known as ‘the pill’; injectable contraception; and male and female condoms.
tsn: tsona di tsenyeletsa dithibelapelegi tse di nwewang, tse di itsegeng ka gore ke "dipilisi"; dithibelapelegi tsa go tlhaba ente; mmogo le mesomelwana ya banna le ya basadi.

eng: what can i do if i’m pregnant?
tsn: nka dira eng fa ke iphitlhela e le gore ke mo mmeleng?

eng: if you think you might be pregnant, take someone you trust with you to your nearest clinic to have a pregnancy test.
tsn: fa e le gore o belaela gore o mo mmeleng, kopa mongwe yo o mo tshepang go ya le wena kwa tleliniking e e gaufi le wena go dira diteko tsa go tlhola fa e le gore o mo mmeleng.

eng: antenatal care (taking care of the unborn baby) is important and usually starts at eight weeks.
tsn: tlhokomelo ya boimana e botlhokwa thata e bile go le gantsi go simololwa ka yano mo bekeng ya borobedi o le mo mmeleng.

eng: your local clinic can help you with antenatal care and a healthcare worker will assist you to develop a plan that is suitable for you and your baby.
tsn: tleliniki ya kwa motseng yo o nnang kwa go ona e ka go thusa ka ditirelo tsa tlhokomelo ya boimana mme motlhankedi wa tlhokomelo ya boitekanelo o tla go thusa go loga leano le le tla tswelang wena le leseanyana la gago le iseng le belegwe mosola.

eng: building a society that works vukuzenzele unnamed the launch of the presidential employment stimulus last week marks a fundamental shift in our ap proach to tackling unem ployment.
tsn: go tsosolosa ikonomi e e re tswelang mosola vukuzenzele unnamed go thankgololwa ga letsholo la madi tshegetso a go tlhola ditiro la moporesitente mo bekeng e e fetileng ke sesupo se segolo mo dikgatong tsa rona tsa go samagana le botlhokatiro.

eng: we are undertaking a farreaching and ambitious public investment in human capital, with the state as both a creator and an enabler of jobs.
tsn: re samagana le dipeeletso tse dikgolo tse di mosola tota tsa setšhaba tsa go beeletsa matlole mo bathong, mo puso e leng yona e tsayang dikgato tsa go kgontsha gore go nne le ditiro e bile gape e le yona e e tlholang ditiro.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus is unprecedented in its scale and breadth, involving a public investment of r100 billion over the next three years.
tsn: letsholo la maditshegetso a go tlhola ditiro la moporesitente ka bogolo jwa lona ga le ise le ke le diragadiwe fa e sale, moo le tsenyeletsang dipeeletso tsa puso tsa bokanaka r100 bilione mo dingwageng di le tharo tse di tlang.

eng: we will protect and create directlyfunded jobs and livelihood support interventions while the labour market recovers from the coronavirus pandemic.
tsn: re tla babalela le go tlhola ditiro tse di tlamelwang ka matlole mmogo le matsholo a a tshegetsang ka fao batho ba iphedisang ka teng go kgontsha maphata a ditiro go itharabologelwa ka bo ona mo leroborobong la mogare wa corona.

eng: each of these is ready for implementation, and is additional to existing commitments.
tsn: e nngwe le e nngwe ya dikgato tseno e letetse fela go tsenngwa tirisong, e bile ke tse dingwe tsa dikgatotlaleletso mo ditsholofetsong tse di leng teng ga jaana.

eng: while some of the interventions build on the strengths of existing programmes, the stimulus also includes new and innovative approaches.
tsn: le fa tota a mangwe a ma tsholo a agelela mo godimo ga manaane a a leng teng ga jaana, letsholo la maditshege tso leno gape le na le dikgato tse dintšhwa tsa boitshimololedi.

eng: this includes a focus on what we have termed ‘social employment’.
tsn: seno se tsenyeletsa go tsepamisa mogopolo mo go seo re se bitsang 'go tlhola ditiro mo mererong ya loago'.

eng: we are working from the premise that there is no shortage of work to be done to address the many social problems in our society.
tsn: re dira tiro eno re tsaya gore go santse go na le namane e tona ya tiro e e santseng e tlhoka go diriwa go ka samagana le matsapa a mantsi a loago a re tobaneng le ona mo setšhabeng sa rona.

eng: the aim is to support the considerable creativity, initiative and institutional capabilities that exist in the wider society to engage people in work that serves the common good.
tsn: maitlhomo a seno ke go tshegetsa matsholo a mantsi a boitlhamedi, boitshimololedi le a bokgoni jwa ditheo jo bo leng teng mo setšhabeng ka bophara go dira gore batho ba iponele ditiro tse di tswelang batho botlhe mosola.

eng: this work cuts across a range of themes, including food security, ending genderbased violence, informal settlement upgrading and much more.
tsn: tiro eno e samagana le mathata a mantsi a a farologaneng, go tsenyeletsa a go nna le tlamelo e e lekaneng ya dijo, go fedisa tirisodikgoka e e totileng batho ba bong jo bo rileng (gbv), go ntšhwafatsa mafelo a baipei mmogo le tse dingwe gape tse dintsintsi.

eng: this will supplement the efforts of the public sector, allowing for greater scale and social impact as well as new forms of partnership with diverse social actors.
tsn: seno se tla tlaleletsa matsapa a lekala la puso, e leng seo se tla kgontshang kgolo e kgolo mmogo le seabe mo loagong go tsenyeetsa le dikgato tse dintšhwa tsa tirisanommogo le bannaleseabe ba ba farologaneng mo loagong.

eng: the stimulus includes a new national programme to employ teaching and school assistants in schools.
tsn: letsholo la maditshegetso leno le tsenyeletsa le leano la naga le lentšhwa le ka lona go tla thapiwang barutabana le bathusi ba barutabana mo dikolong.

eng: schools are making these appointments right now, delivering new opportunities in every community across the length and breadth of the country.
tsn: kwa dikolong go tsweletswe ka go thapa batho bano, go bulela ditšhono tse dinšhwa mo nageng eno ka bophara.

eng: public employment is not just for unskilled work.
tsn: tirelopuso ga se fela ya batho ba ba senang bokgoni.

eng: there is a crosscutting focus on graduates, with opportunities for nurses, science graduates, artisans and others.
tsn: go na gape le ditiro tse di batlang batho ba ba alogileng, mo ditirong tsa booking, tsa dialogane tsa dithuto tsa saense, tsa badiri ba ditiro tsa diatla mmogo le ditiro tse dingwe gape tse dintsi.

eng: the stimulus will also protect jobs in vulnerable sectors that have been hit hard by the pandemic.
tsn: letsholo la maditshegetso leno le tla tshegetsa gape le ditiro mo makaleng a a ntseng a le mo ketsaetsegong a leroborobo leno le sa a direlang molemo le e seng.

eng: support will be provided to early childhood development practitioners, mainly selfemployed women.
tsn: go tla tshegediwa badiredi ba mafelo a thuto ya bomapimpana (ecd), bogolosegolo basadi ba ba ithapileng mo mafelong ano.

eng: over 74,000 small farmers will also receive production input grants.
tsn: balemirui ba ba potlana ba feta ba le 74 000 le bona ba tla neelwa madithuso a go ba thusa ka tlhagiso ya ditsweletswa tsa bona.

eng: as a nation, we need arts and culture to lift our spirits once more – the stimulus provides new funding to help the sector back onto its feet, including support to digital contentcreation and expansion of ecommerce platforms.
tsn: re le naga re tlhoka gore ba ditirelo tsa botsweretshi le setso ba tsosolose mewa ya rona – mme letsholo leno la maditshegetso le tlamela ka matlole go thusa lekala leno gore le boele le ikemele ka maoto a lona a mabedi, go tsenyeletsa le go tshegetsa tlhagiso ya mananeo a dijithale mmogo le go atolosa mabe ntlele a a rekisang dilwana mo diraleng tsa inthanete.

eng: this will enable artists to adapt to the new market conditions that the pandemic has imposed on us all and to seize new opportunities for growth.
tsn: seno se tla kgontsha badiragatsi gore ba itlwaetse maemo a mantšhwa mo marakeng ao a tlisitsweng ke leroborobo leno mo go rona rotlhe mmogo le go ithopela ditšhono tse dintšhwa tsa kgolo ya ikonomi.

eng: a critical enabler for wider job creation, made more important by the pandemic, is connectivity.
tsn: mobuladikgoro yo o botlho kwa thata mo go tlholeng ditiro, yo leroborobo leno le dirileng gore a nne botlhokwa le go gaisa, ke kgokelelo ya inthanete.

eng: to overcome the digital divide, the stimulus will provide affordable, highspeed broadband to lowincome households through innovative connection subsidies and the expansion of free public wifi.
tsn: gore re fedise go tlhoka tekatekano mo go fitlheleleng didirisiwa tsa dijithale, letsholo la maditshegetso leno le tla tlamela malapa a a iponelang merokotso e mennye ka porotebente e e rekegang e e nang le lebelo le le kwa godimo ka go dirisa mekgwa ya boitshimololedi ya go duelela karolo nngwe ya dituelelo tsa dikgokagano tsa inthanete mmogo le go atolosa wifi e e sa duelelweng e e dirisiwang ke baagi mo setšhabeng.

eng: as our country recovers from the devastation of the coronavirus pandemic, we are in no doubt as to the size of the task before us.
tsn: jaaka naga ya rona e itharabologelwa mo matsading a le roborobo la mogare wa corona, ga re na ketsaetsego epe fa go tla mo bogolong jwa tiro e re tobaneng le yona.

eng: we have to achieve an economic recovery that is swift and inclusive.
tsn: re tshwanetse go tlhola itharabologelo ya ikonomi ya ka bonako e bile e tsenyeletsa bo tlhe.

eng: we have to get as many of our people as possible working again.
tsn: re tshwanetse go tlholela batho ba borona ba bantsi ditiro.

eng: we also have to regain lost ground in the provision of basic services and critical infrastructure, addressing social challenges and transforming townships and rural communities too.
tsn: re tlhoka gape le go boela sekeng fa go tla mo kabelong ya ditirelo tsa motheo mmogo le mo kabelong ya mafaratlha tlha a setšhaba a a botlhokwa, fa go tla mo go samaganeng le dikgwetlho mo loagong mmogo le mo go tlhabololeng makeišene le metse ya selegae.

eng: public employment is an instrument that can do all of the above: creating jobs at scale in the short term while markets recover, and creating social value in the process.
tsn: tirelopuso ke sedirisiwa se se ka dirisiwang go samagana le tsotlhe tse di fa godimo: ka go tlhola ditiro tse dintsi mo nakong e khutshwane fa mo letlhakoreng le lengwe dimaraka di itharabologelwa, mmogo le go tlhola ditlhokwa tsa loago.

eng: the example is often cited of the massive public works programme undertaken by the united states after the great depression in the 1930s.
tsn: gantsi go a tle go dirisiwe seka sa go dirisa lenaane la ditiro tsa puso jaaka naga ya amerika e ne ya dira morago ga gore e itemogele phutlhamo ya muruo mo dingwageng tsa bo 1930. eno e ne e se fela kgato ya letsholo la maditshegetso, e ne gape e le kgato ya go tsholetsa go nna le seabe mo loagong ga batho botlhe.

eng: there are several examples of innovative public employment programmes in the developing world, including in india, ethiopia and here in south africa.
tsn: go na le dikao di le dintsinyana tsa boitshimololedi fa go tla mo manaaneng a ditiro tsa puso mo dinageng tse di tlhabologang, go tsenyeletsa naga ya india, ya ethiopia mmogo le e re leng mo go yona eno ya aforika borwa.

eng: these programmes make a direct investment in local economies, reaching poorer areas first, supporting local small enterprises and trickling up into the wider economy from there.
tsn: manaane ano a beeletsa ka tolamo mo diikonoming tsa ka fa nageng, mo di tswelang mosola pele mafelo a go nnang batho ba ba humanegileng mo go ona, a tshegetsa dikgwebopotlana tsa ka fa nageng mmogo le go tsena mo ikonoming e e bulegileng go tloga fano.

eng: they also promote social participation and inclusion, providing communities with the means to change their lives as they undertake new forms of work.
tsn: a tshegetsa gape le go nna le seabe mo mererong ya loago le eo e tsenyeletsang batho botlhe, e leng seo se kgontshang baagi go fetola matshelo a bona jaaka ba tsaya ditiro tse dingwe tse dintšhwa.

eng: in doing so, they contribute to transformation both at a local level and within broader society.
tsn: ka go dira jalo a nna le seabe mo go refosaneng maemo mo maemong ka bobedi a ka fa nageng le a mo setšhabeng ka kakaretso.

eng: direct public investment to support employment and create economic opportunities that generate social value does more than just tackle the unemployment crisis.
tsn: dipeeletso tse di lolameng tsa puso tse di tshegetsang ditiro le go tlhola ditšhono tsa ikonomi tse di nang le boleng mo loagong di na le mosola o mogolo go gaisa wa go samaganana le matsapa a botlhokatiro.

eng: it is responsive, because it uses the state’s resources to respond to local community needs, be it for greener spaces, food security, more early childhood development centres, or for better and more accessible roads.
tsn: di a tsibogela, ka ntlha ya gore di dirisa metswedi ya puso go samagana le ditlho kwa tsa baagi, e ka tswa e le mabapi le go somarela tlhago, go tlhagisa dijo tse di sa tlhaeleng, go bula mafelo a mangwe gape a ecd, kgotsa e ka tswa e le mabapi le go aga ditsela tse dingwe gape tse di botoka tse di fitlhelesegang.

eng: it is progressive, because it offers social protection and income security to those who face destitution because they are unable to find work.
tsn: di tlisa kgatelopele gonne di dira gore batho ba ba humanegileng ba iponele tlhokomelo ya loago le go itirela megolo ka ntlha ya fa ba sa kgone go ka bona ditiro.

eng: it is an investment in the future, in that it supports the broader economic recovery agenda by urgently getting our people to work on improving our national and municipal infrastructure.
tsn: ke dipeeletso tsa mo isagong gonne di tshegetsa mogopolo o mogolo wa itharabologelo ya ikonomi ka go dira gore ka ponyo ya leitlho batho ba borona ba bone ditiro tsa go tokafatsa mafaratlhatlha a rona a naga le a mebasepala.

eng: through the interventions in the stimulus, we are creating work for those who need it, while leaving a lasting impact on entire communities.
tsn: ka ditharabololo tse di tlisiwang ke letsholo leno la ma ditshegetso, re tlholela batho ba ba senang ditiro ditiro, fa ka fa letlhakoreng le lengwe baagi botlhe ba tla bona mosola wa go ya go ile mo go seno.

eng: like public employment programmes across the world, this employment stimulus supports and complements the critical role of the private sector in creating jobs.
tsn: fela jaaka lenaane la ditiro tsa puso mo lefatsheng ka bophara, letsholo leno la maditshegetso a ditiro le tshegetsa le go thusana le seabe se se botlhokwa se makala a poraefete a nang le sona mo go tlholeng ditiro.

eng: it is countercyclical, in that as the recovery advances, the scale of public employment will decline.
tsn: kgato eno e a kgarametsana ka ntlha ya gore fa itharabologelo ya ikonomi e ntse e gola, ditiro tsa puso le tsona di tla fokotsega.

eng: the work experience and skills acquired by beneficiaries of the presidential employment stimulus will improve their prospects of securing formal employment.
tsn: fela maitemogelo le bokgoni jo bajalefa bano ba letsholo la maditshegetso a go tlhola ditiro la moporesitente ba tla bong ba iponetse one a tla ba thusa mo go iponeleng ditiro tsa semmuso.

eng: the experience gained is also a pathway to entrepreneurial activity.
tsn: maitemogelo a ba iponetseng ona gape a ka ba tswela mosola mo go itlhameleng dikgwebo.

eng: participants will improve their skills and capabilities to start their own businesses, and can use the steady income provided by public employment to branch out into other incomegenerating activities.
tsn: bannaleseabe ba tla tokafatsa bokgoni jwa bona gore ba kgone go itshimololela dikgwebo tsa bona, mmogo le go dirisa mogolo o o sa kgaotseng o ba tla bong ba o amogela go tswa mo ditirong tsa puso go itshimololela ditiro tse di tla ba tlisetsang letseno.

eng: i have consistently affirmed that the covid19 crisis is also a window of opportunity to build back better.
tsn: ke tsweletse go totobatsa ka tolamo gore matsapa a a tlisi tsweng ke covid19 re tshwanetse go a bona gape jaaka tšhono ya go aga sešwa sentle.

eng: at this time of great upheaval, we would be doing ourselves no favours by making unrealistic promises that raise expectations, only to come short when they are not met.
tsn: mo nakong e tshwana le e, e e aparetsweng ke mathata a gana go fela, re tla bo re sa itirele molemo go dira ditsholofetso tse re itseng gore di ka se kgonagale ka go dira gore batho ba nne le tsholofelo mo go rona, mme re bo re retele lwa ke go diragatsa jaaka re solofeditse.

eng: this is why each of the jobs and livelihood support interventions is fully funded, with a clear implementation plan.
tsn: ke ka ntlha ya seo re dirileng gore tharabololo ya tshegetso ya tiro nngwe le nngwe e tlamelwe ka matlole ka botlalo, mme go nne le leano le le tlhamaletseng la tiragatso.

eng: the employment stimulus is not about vague commitments for some time in the future, but about jobs being created right here and now.
tsn: letsholo la maditshegetso a ditiro ga se maikano a a loleya a re sa itseng gore a tswa kae a lebile kae a a tla diragadiwang mo isagong, fela le ka ga ditiro tse di tlhamiwang jaanong mo re leng teng jaana mo motsing o re leng mo go ona.

eng: the stimulus is the result of extensive consultation with national departments, provinces and metros to rapidly design employment pro grammes that can be rolled out or expanded within six months.
tsn: letsholo la maditshegetso leno le nnile teng go latela dikgato tse di telele tse di tseneletseng tsa go bontshana le mafapha a naga, a porofense le a dimasepala tse dikgolo gore di tlhole ka bonako manaane a ditiro a a ka tlhagisiwang kgotsa a tlhatlosiwa mo pakeng ya dikgwedi di le thataro.

eng: the implementing departments and other stakeholders were rigorously assessed on their capacity to implement.
tsn: mafapha a a tshwanetseng go goga manaane ano kwa pele a ne a sekasekiwa ka tsenelelo go bona fa a na le bokgoni jwa go ka diragatsa tiro eno.

eng: in every one of the programmes that fall under the stimulus, opportunities will be widely advertised and recruitment will be fair, open and transparent.
tsn: mo lenaaneng le lengwe le le lengwe le le welang mo letsholong la maditshegetso leno, ditšhono tsa teng di tla phasaladiwa ka botlalo mme dikgato tsa go thapa batho e tla nna tse di sa tseeng letlhakore, tse di buletsweng batho botlhe e bile di sena lehunelo.

eng: the goals we have set ourselves are realistic, measura ble and achievable, and draw lessons from past experience and international best prac tice.
tsn: dipeelo tse re ipeetseng tsone ke tsa nnete, di a kgwanthisisega e bile di a kgonega, e bile re ithutile mo diphosong tsa mo malobeng le go tswa mo ditirong tsa boditšhabatšhaba tsa go dira tiro sentle.

eng: our people are ready and willing to work.
tsn: batho ba rona ba eme sejaro e bile ba ikemiseditse go dira.

eng: this vast potential must be harnessed, and our collective skills and capabilities brought to bear in rebuilding our country in the wake of the coronavirus.
tsn: maikemisetso ano a mantsi a tshwanetse go solwa mosola, mme bokgoni jwa rona botlhe bo tshwanetse bo re tswele mosola mo go age sešwa naga ya rona fa re itharabologelwa mo mogareng wa corona.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus provides a respite for families who have endured a long hard winter with greatly reduced income, and for individuals who have spent many years without work.
tsn: letsholo la maditshegetso a go tlhola ditiro la moporesitente le neelana ka phimolakeledi mo malapeng a a itshoketseng mariga a matelele a a boima ka mogolo o o neng o ngotlilwe thata, mmogo le mo baaging ba ba ntseng ba sena ditiro sebaka sa dingwaga di sena palo.

eng: avoid becoming a human trafficking victim silusapho nyanda as the number of human trafficking cases being reported increases, it is important that you take steps to ensure your safety.
tsn: tila go nna motswase tlhabelo wa go utswiwa silusapho nyanda jaaka palo ya dikge tse tse di begiwang tsa batho ba ba utswiwang e tlhatloga, go botlhokwa gore o tsaye dikgato gore o babalesege.

eng: to avoid becoming a victim of trafficking, you should avoid travelling alone at night or on deserted streets.
tsn: go tila go nna motswa setlhabelo wa go utswiwa o tshwanetse go kgaotsa go tsamaya o le esi, go tsamaya bosigo kgotsa go tsamaya mo mebileng e go senang batho mo go yona.

eng: it is important that you are aware of your surroundings at all times.
tsn: go botlhokwa thata gore o ele tlhoko se se diragalang mo tikologong e o leng mo go yona ka dinako tsotlhe.

eng: being alert will help spot something that is out of place.
tsn: go nna kelotlhoko go tla go thusa gore o kgone go bona sengwe le sengwe se se diragalang se se belae tsang.

eng: if you notice a person or a car following you, find a crowded place and contact the police or someone you trust immediately.
tsn: fa o ka lemoga gore go na le motho kgotsa sejanaga se se go setseng morago, feresella mo go tletseng batho mme o letsetse sepodisi mogala kgotsa o letsetse motho mongwe le mongwe yo o mo tshepang mogala ka bonako.

eng: traffickers often use the promise of a job to kidnap their victims and will approach potential victims offering them a job or some kind of opportunity.
tsn: batho ba ba utswang batho ba bangwe ba dirisa tsholofetso ya tiro jaaka sedirisiwa sa go utswa batswasetlhabelo mme ba ikgolaganya le motho yo a bonagalang e ka nna motswasetlhabelo go mo solofetsa tiro kgotsa tšhono ya mothale yo o rileng.

eng: this form of trafficking can happen anywhere – even on social media, at school, in the mall and outside your house.
tsn: tiro eno ya go utswa batho e ka diragala gongwe le gongwe – tota le mo mafaratlhatlheng a ditlhaeletsano, kwa sekolong, kwa marekelong le fa pele ga lefelo leo o nnang kwa go lona.

eng: make sure you conduct thorough research on potential employers before going to meet them in person for interviews.
tsn: netefatsa gore o dira dipatlisiso tse di tseneletseng ka batho ba ba batlang go go thapa pele o ka ya go kopana le bona.

eng: this can be done by verifying that the company really exists by checking with the companies and intellectual property commission.
tsn: o ka dira seno ka go batlisisa gore a setlamo seo se teng ka boammaruri ka go se tlhola mo go companies and intellectual property commission (cipc).

eng: you should also tell some one you trust when you are going to an interview and arrange for them to call you after a certain amount of time.
tsn: o tlhoka gape le go laela mongwe yo o mo tshepang fa o ya dikopanong tsa go senka tiro mme o mo kope le gore a go letsetse morago ga sebaka se se rileng.

eng: if possible, have someone go with you.
tsn: fa go kgonega, o kope mongwe go go felegetsa.

eng: be careful when using social media, especially when a stranger offers to help, offers money, a place to stay or a job opportunity in response to something you posted.
tsn: itlhokomele fa o dirisa mafaratlhatlha a ditlhaeletsano, bogolosegolo fa motho yo o sa mo itseng a batla go go thusa ka go go naya madi, go go naya lefelo la bodulo kgotsa tiro ka ntlha ya sengwe se o se phasaladitseng mo mafaratlhatlheng ano.

eng: if you are going out to meet someone new, do so at a public place and let someone you trust know where you are.
tsn: fa e le gore o a ikentsha mme o ya go kopana le motho yo o sa mo itseng, kopana le motho yoo mo lefelong leo go nang le batho mo go lona mme o bolelele mongwe yo o mo tshepang gore o tswetse kae.

eng: when going out with children, keep them close and make sure you can see them at all times.
tsn: fa o ikentsha le bana, netefatsa gore ba tsamaela gaufi le wena le gore ga ba tikele mo o sa kgoneng go ba bona teng.

eng: you should never send a child on an errand without a trusted adult to watch over them.
tsn: ga o a tshwanela go roma ngwana go sena motho yo mogolo yo o tshepagalang yo a mo tlhomileng leitlho.

eng: recovery on the horizon for sa vukuzenzele unnamed the jacaranda trees are in full bloom across the nation’s capital, heralding the start of summer.
tsn: itharabologelo ya ikonomi ya aforika borwa e a solofetsa vukuzenzele unnamed ditlhare tsa jakaranta di thuntse go ralala le teropokgolo ya naga eno, e leng sesupo sa gore selemo se gorogile.

eng: after a long and difficult winter, the beginning of a new season should fill us with optimism.
tsn: morago ga mariga a a go gileng sebaka a a neng a le bokete, go goroga ga setlha se sentšhwa go tshwanetse go re rotloetsa.

eng: when the national state of disaster was declared in march, our immediate priority was to contain the spread of the virus and provide emergency relief to citizens, communities, workers and businesses.
tsn: fa naga e ne e tsena mo mae mong a masetlapelo a naga ka kgwedi ya mopitlwe, tiro ya rona ya ntlha e ne e le go thibela go anama ga mogare le go thusa baagi, badiri le dikgwebo.

eng: over the course of eight months and with the support of our social partners, we rolled out a comprehensive set of measures to limit the social and economic impact of the pandemic.
tsn: mo sebakeng sa dikgwedi di le robedi ka tshegetso ya badirisanimmogo ba rona mo mererong ya loago, re tlha gisitse dikgato tse di nang le mmoko di le dintsinyana go fokotsa bogale jwa lero borobo leno mo loagong le mo ikonoming.

eng: we massively expanded social protection on a scale that has never been attempted before in this country.
tsn: re diragaditse letsholo le legolo thata la tlhokomelo ya loago le naga eno e iseng e le bone.

eng: we are one of the few countries in the world where the right of access to social security is enshrined in the constitution, and we can be proud that during this grave crisis we gave practical expression to this right in many ways.
tsn: re e nngwe ya dinaga di le mmalwa mo lefatsheng mo tshwanelo ya go amo gela tlhokomelo ya loago e tsholeditsweng ke molao theo, e bile re tshwanetse go ipela gore mo nakong eno e e neng e le bokete re kgonne go diragatsa tshwanelo eno ka ditsela tse di farologaneng.

eng: in addition to our existing social grants, which reach more than 17 million people every month, we toppedup the old age, disability and child support grants.
tsn: mo godimo ga megolo ya loago e re nang le yona, e e neelwang kgwedi le kgwe di go batho ba feta ba le 17 milione, re ne ra oketsa megolo ya bagodi, megolo ya batho ba ba tshelang ka bogolofadi le megolo ya tshegetso ya bana.

eng: we rolled out a special coronavirus disease (covid19) social relief of distress grant, which has reached some six million people to date.
tsn: re ne ra tlhagisa mogolo wa go thusa baagi wa mogolo o o itlhophileng wa covid19 , o o setseng o thusitse batho ba le dimilione di le thataro go fitlha mo motsing ono.

eng: this was done within weeks of the national state of disaster being declared.
tsn: seno se diragaditswe mora gonyana fela ga dibeke di se kae go tloga mo motsing o re itsisitseng fa re tsena mo maemong a masetlapelo a naga.

eng: to bring this system online there was extensive collaboration between the south african social security agency, south african revenue service, home affairs and many others.
tsn: gore re tsenye ti risong thulaganyo eno ya mo inthaneteng go nnile le tirisa nommogo e kgolo magareng ga setheo sa tshireletso ya loago sa aforika borwa (sassa), tirelo ya lekgetho la aforika borwa (sars), lefapha la merero ya sele gae mmogo le maphata a mangwe a mantsi.

eng: we set up a fully automated application and disbursement process, and integrated multiple databases, including the national population register and the unemployment insurance fund (uif) database.
tsn: re ne ra tlhoma thulaganyo ya go araba dikopo e e ara biwang ka botlalo ke kho mphiutara mmogo le ya go duelela megolo eno, ra gokelela difalanatshedimo setso di le dintsi mo go yona, go tsenyeletsa le rejisetara ya baagi ba ka fa nageng mmo go le sefalanatshedimoso sa ba letlole la go kgaolwa kwa tirong (uif).

eng: we set up new application channels like whatsapp and ussd, and created systems with the commercial banks to enable banking detail verification.
tsn: re ne ra tsenya tirisong mekgwa e mešwa ya go dira dikopo e e jaaka whatsapp le ussd, mmogo le go tlhoma dithulaganyo tsa dibanka tsa tirelo ya baagi go kgontsha gore dintlha tsa baagi tsa kwa bankeng di tlhotlhomisiwe bonolo.

eng: this is a remarkable achievement in a very short space of time.
tsn: eno ke tiro e ntle e le ruri e e dirilweng ka katlego mo nakong e khutshwane thata.

eng: alongside the measures we took to protect and sustain livelihoods, we also supported ailing businesses.
tsn: fela jaaka go le mo dikga tong tsa rona tsa go babalela le go tshegetsa ka fao batho ba itshedisang ka teng, re dira fela jalo le mo dikgwebong tse di kgobang ka mpa.

eng: we provided relief to small businesses in the form of debt relief, finance, tax payment deferrals and other instruments.
tsn: re thusa dikgwebopotlana ka go di kgaotsetsa sekoloto, ka go di tlamela ka matlole, ka go diegisa paka ya gore di duelele lekgetho le ka go dirisa e mengwe ya mekgwa ya mothale ono.

eng: we implemented a covid19 loan guarantee scheme to enable businesses to meet their operational expenses during the lockdown, and are currently looking at how this scheme can reach more companies in need.
tsn: re tsentse tirisong sekema sa tshegetso sa madikadimo sa covid19 go kgontsha dikgwebo gore di kgone go iponela madi a go tsamaisa dikgwebo mo pakeng ya fa re ne re le mo dikgatong tsa go sekega nakwana ditiro tsa ka fa nageng, mme jaanong re atlhaatlhaa ntlha ya gore sekema seno se ka dirisiwa jang go thusa tse dingwe tsa ditlamo tse dintsi tse di tlhokang thuso eno.

eng: we provided income protection to workers and relief to business owners through the temporary employer relief scheme administered by the uif.
tsn: re neile beng ba dikgwe bo madi a a tla thusang gore badiri ba se felelwe ke mogolo ka go neelana ka sekema sa nakwana sa go thusa bathapi se se laolwang ke uif.

eng: these were all in direct response to an emergency and were by nature temporary.
tsn: tseno tsotlhe di dirilwe e le maiteko a go samagana le maemo a tshoganyetso a re neng re tobane le one ao boammaruri e leng a nakwana.

eng: some are now coming to an end, while others have been extended as the labour market recovers.
tsn: tse dingwe tsa dikema tseno di felelwa ke nako fa gautshwane, mme tse dingwe di okeleditswe nako jaaka maphata a badiri a itharabologelwa.

eng: the measures we implemented went a long way towards protecting our society from the harsh winds of covid19.
tsn: dikgato tse re di tsereng di nnile mosola thata mo go sireletseng baagi ba rona mo matlhotlhapelong a a tlisi tsweng ke covid19 .

eng: the additional grants helped to prevent millions of people from falling below the food poverty line.
tsn: madithuso a mangwe gape a tlaleletso a thusitse batho ba le dimilionemilione gore ba se gosomele mo lehumeng.

eng: had we not intervened to secure livelihoods and save businesses, the living conditions of our people and the circumstances of thousands of businesses would have been considerably worse.
tsn: fa re ne re ka bo re sa tsaya dikgato mo go tshegetseng ka fao batho ba iphedisang ka teng mmogo le go thusa gore dikgwebo di se phu tlhame, maemo a batho ba rona mmogo le a diketekete tsa dikgwebo a ne a ka bo a le maswe go feta a ga jaanong.

eng: now we are in a transition from relief to recovery.
tsn: jaanong re samagane le go fetola maemo go tloga mo a go thusa mme re lebile a go itharabologelwa ga ikonomi.

eng: the emergency measures we put in place have laid a firm foundation on which to rebuild our economy.
tsn: dikgato tsa tshoganye tso tse re di tsereng di agile motheo o o tsetsepetseng o mo go ona re tla agang sešwa ikonomi ya rona.

eng: as our focus now shifts to the implementation of the economic reconstruction and recovery plan, our priority will be to stimulate growth and create jobs.
tsn: jaanong jaaka maitlhomo a rona a fetoga go samagana le leano la itharabologelo le kagosešwa ya ikonomi, maitlhomo a rona e tla nna a go tlhotlheletsa kgolo ya ikonomi le go tlhola ditiro.

eng: there has already been progress in a number of areas.
tsn: go setse go na le kgatelopele e e dirilweng mo dikarolong di le dintsinyana.

eng: we are seeing new funding commitments for infrastructure development following an infrastructure project roundtable last week.
tsn: re bona maikano a mangwe a mantšhwa a go tlamela di kgato tsa tlhabololo ya mafa ratlhatlha ka matlole go latela dipuisano tse di tshwerweng mo bekeng e e fetileng tse di ka ga diporojeke tsa mafa ratlhatlha.

eng: a number of employment programmes under the presidential employment stimulus have started.
tsn: manaane a le mantsinyana a letsholo la maditshegetso a go tlhola ditiro la moporesi tente a setse a simolotse.

eng: we are pushing ahead with economic reforms in areas such as energy and telecommunications.
tsn: re gatela pele ka mananeo a go busetsa sekeng maemo a ikonomi mo dikarolong tse di jaaka tsa motlakase le tsa mafaratlhatlha a ditlhaele tsano.

eng: plans are being converted to action and commitments are being reflected in jobs and opportunities.
tsn: maano jaanong a setse a diragadiwa mme maikano a a dirilweng re a bona mo ditšhonong tsa ditiro.

eng: it is all the more critical at this time, more so with the festive season approaching, that we do not become the architects of our own undoing.
tsn: go botlhokwa mo nakong e re leng mo go yona eno, bo golo jang ka re atumela paka ya melemo ya bokhutlho jwa ngwaga, gore re se itobele dintshi.

eng: the greatest vigilance is required from us all to keep the virus at bay.
tsn: go tlhokega gore re itlho komele thata gore mogare ono o tshamekele kgakala le rona.

eng: a resurgence at any scale will not just dramatically reverse our health gains.
tsn: go runyasešwa ga bolwetse jono ga go kitla go ama fela bogolosegolo tseo re di di rileng mo maemong a boite kanelo.

eng: it will choke the green shoots of economic recovery that have emerged, and take us back from spring to winter.
tsn: go tla gatelela gape le dikgato tsa rona tsa itha rabologelo ya ikonomi tse re setseng re di simolotse, mme tsa re busetsa kwa morago kwa lowe mo letlhafuleng le mo marigeng a re fitileng mo go ona.

eng: to prevent a second wave of covid19 infections, we must observe the public health guidelines that remain in place.
tsn: fa re batla go efoga ditira galo tsa go runya lekgetlo la bobedi ga ditshwaetso tsa covid19 , re tshwanetse go obamela dikaelo tsa setšhaba tsa boitekanelo tse di sa ntseng di le mo tirisong.

eng: when we fail to wear a mask at a social gathering, when we attend crowded events, we are not only putting ourselves and others at risk.
tsn: fa re sa apare dimaseke mo go nang le batho, fa re tsena mo go tletseng matšhwititšhwiti a batho gone, ga re baye rona le batho ba bangwe fela mo kotsing.

eng: we are also putting our economic recovery in jeopardy.
tsn: re baya gape mo kotsing le dikgato tsa rona tsa go tso solosa ikonomi ya rona.

eng: let us all continue to play our part.
tsn: a rotlhe re tsweleleng go tshameka karolo ya rona.

eng: the positive actions of wearing a mask, of maintaining social distancing and of regular hand washing helped us overcome the worst effects of the pandemic.
tsn: dikgato tse di nang le mo sola tsa go apara dimaseke, tsa go katogana le tsa go tlhapa diatla ka gale di re thusitse go finyelela mo bogaleng jwa ditlamorago tsa leroborobo leno.

eng: healthdrink water to avoid dehydration allison cooper severe heat and not drinking enough fluids can lead to dehydration and heatstroke, which can be fatal.
tsn: enwa metsi gore o se felelwe ke metsi mo mmeleng allison cooper mogote yo o bogale le go se nwe dilo tse di metsi go ka dira gore o felelwe ke metsi mo mmeleng le go tshwarwa ke bolwetse jwa go swa letlhakore ka ntlha ya mogote, e leng se se kotsi thata.

eng: according to the western cape department of health, the summer heat brings with it a high risk of dehydration, which is a harmful loss of water in the body.
tsn: go ya ka lefapha la boitekanelo la porofense ya kapa bophirima, mogote wa selemo o tlisa dikotsi tse di tsamaisanang le bolwetse jwa go felelwa ke metsi mo mmeleng, e leng bolwetse jo bo kotsi thata jwa go felelwa ke metsi mo mmeleng.

eng: dehydration is usually caused by not drinking enough liquids to replenish the water lost by sweating.
tsn: go felelwa ke metsi mo mmeleng go le gantsi go tlhodiwa ke go se nwe dilo tse di lekaneng tsa go nna le metsi go tlaleletsa metsi a a tswileng mo mmeleng wa gago ka ntlha ya go fufulelwa.

eng: it can also be caused by an illness, that causes vomiting or diarrhoea; and by sweating from a fever.
tsn: bo ka tlhodiwa gape le ke bolwetse jo bo dirang gore motho a tlhatse kgotsa a ntshe letshololo; le go fufulelwa ka ntlha ya go fisa mo mmeleng.

eng: the loss of body fluids does not only occur during hard physical activities, but can also result from walking, gardening or riding a bike, especially in hot or humid conditions.
tsn: go fufulelwa ga go tlhole fela ke fa o ikatisa ka thata mo mmeleng, go tlhodiwa gape le ke fa o tsamaya ka maoto, o dira mo tshingwaneng ya gago kgotsa o kganna gategate ya gago, bogolo jang fa kwa ntle go le bolelo kgotsa go le bongola.

eng: when you are dehydrated, your body cannot function as usual.
tsn: fa o feletswe ke metsi mo mmeleng, mmele wa gago ga o sa dira sentle ka fao o o tlwaetseng.

eng: children younger than five, the elderly and people working outdoors are especially vulnerable to dehydration and heatstroke (a condition caused when your body overheats).
tsn: bana ba dingwaga tse di ka fa tlase ga di le tlhano, batsofe le batho ba tiro ya bona e ba gapeletsang go dira ba le kwa ntle ke bona ba ba leng mo kotsing e kgolo go gaisa ya go ka tshwarwa ke bolwetse jwa go felelwa ke metsi mo mmeleng le go swa letlhakore ka ntlha ya mogote (e leng bolwetse jo bo tlhodiwang ke fa mmele wa gago o fisa go feta tekano).

eng: heatstroke is a medical emergency.
tsn: go swa letlhakore ka ntlha ya mogote ke bolwetse jo bo tlhokang go lekolwa ka tshoganyetso.

eng: seek medical help immediately for any of these symptoms: feeling confused or your speech starts to become slow and unclear.
tsn: fa o itemogela e nngwe le e nngwe ya matshwao ano ikopanye le ba ditirelo tsa boitekanelo: fa o sa itlhaloganye kgotsa fa o simolola go nna loleya fa o re o a bua kgotsa o sa utlwagale le gore o a reng.

eng: nausea and vomiting.
tsn: go feroga dibete le go tlhatsa.

eng: dehydration warning signssome of the early warning signs of dehydration include: feeling thirsty and lightheaded.
tsn: matshwao a gore o na le bolwetse jwa go felelwa ke metsi mo mmelenga mangwe a matshwao a go sa le gale a bolwetse jwa go felelwa ke metsi mo mmeleng a tsenyeletsa: go ikutlwa o nyorilwe e bile o dikwelela go se nene.

eng: a dry mouth.
tsn: go oma molomo.

eng: having dark coloured, strongsmelling urine.
tsn: go rota moroto o o nang le mmala o o tseneletseng, ka monkgo o o nkgang thata.

eng: to stay hydrated and avoid heatstroke you should: drink more water than you usually do on hot days.
tsn: gore o se felelwe ke metsi mo mmeleng le gore o se swe letlhakore ka ntlha ya mogote: fa go le bolelo e nwa metsi a mantsi go feta ao o tlwaetseng go a anwa.

eng: stay inside or in shaded areas.
tsn: nna ka fa teng ga meago kgotsa mo mafelong ao a nang le meriti.

eng: wear a wide rim hat or use an umbrella.
tsn: apara lephepha le le pharaletseng kgotsa o dirise amborela.

eng: always carry a bottle of water with you and drink regularly.
tsn: tsamaya o tshotse botlolo ya metsi mo go wena gongwe le gongwe ko o yang gone mme o a nwe gangwe le gape.

eng: take regular breaks from the sun if you work outside.
tsn: fa e le gore tiro ya gago ke ya kwa ntle mo go nang le letsatsi, gangwe le gape o nne o ntse o ikhutsa mo meriting.

eng: cool yourself down by using a spray bottle.
tsn: itshele ka metsi ka lebotlolo la go ifafatsa gore o fokotse mogote mo mmeleng.

eng: babies and childrenparents and caregivers should pay extra attention to children and babies, to make sure they are hydrated.
tsn: masea le bana batsadi le basalalebana ba tshwanetse go tlhokomela thata masea le bana ba ba leng mo tlhokomelong ya bona, ka go netefatsa gore ga ba felelwe ke metsi mo mmeleng.

eng: breastfeeding moms should feed their babies more frequently when it is very hot.
tsn: batsadi ba ba anyisang masea a bona letswele ba tshwanetse go ba anyisa gangwe le gape fa go le mogote.

eng: keep children indoors or in the shade, dress them in light clothing and wipe them down with a damp cloth to help them stay cool.
tsn: a bana ba nne ka fa teng ga meago kgotsa kwa meriting, ba apesiwe diaparo tse di bofefo le go nna le ba phimola ka lesela le le kolobeditsweng gore le ba fokoletse mogote mo mmeleng.

eng: remember to apply sunscreen when they go outdoors.
tsn: gopola go ba tshasa ka setshaso sa go sireletsa letlalo mo letsatsing fa ba tswela kwa ntle.

eng: if children younger than five have watery stools, keep vomiting and are tired, seek medical help immediately.
tsn: fa bana ba ba ka fa tlase ga dingwaga di le tlhano ba tsweletse go tsholola, go tlhatsa e bile ba nyemelela, ikopanye le ba boitekanelo.

eng: also seek immediate medical care if your baby is unable to breastfeed or has sunken eyes and a sunken soft spot (fontanelle) on its head.
tsn: ikopanye le ba boitekanelo gape fa e le gore leseanyana la gago ga le batle go anya kgotsa matlho a lona a gonyetse le phogwana le yona e wetse.

eng: in children, other dehydration warning signs include: a dry or sticky mouth.
tsn: mo baneng, matshwao a mangwe gape a a bontshang gore ba felelwa ke metsi mo mmeleng a tsenyeletsa: go oma le go kgomarela melongwana.

eng: few or no tears when crying.
tsn: go tswa dikeledi tse dinnye kgotsa go se tswe dikeledi fa ba lela.

eng: urinating less or fewer wet nappies than usual.
tsn: go rota moroto o monnye kgotsa go nna le mengatonyana e le mmalwanyana fela e a e rotetseng go gaisa ya ka gale.

eng: sa overcoming hiv and aids vukuzenzele unnamed as we continue our efforts to manage the devastating coronavirus pandemic, we cannot ignore the other public health challenges that our country faces.
tsn: aforika borwa e itharabologelwa mo bolwetseng jwa hiv le aids vukuzdenzele unnamed jaaka re tswelela ka matsapa a rona go samagana le leroborobo leno le le dirang tlhakantsuke la mogare wa corona , re ka se ikgatolose dikgwetlho tse dingwe tse re tobaneng le tsona mo laphateng la boitekanelo ka fa nageng ya rona.

eng: for more than three dec ades, our country has been engaged in an ongoing struggle against hiv and aids, which has cost many lives and caused great hardship and suffering.
tsn: e setse e le sebaka sa dingwagasome di le tharo naga ya rona e kgaratlha ka ntlha ya mogare wa lebolelateng (hiv) le lebolelateng (aids), e leng seo se dirileng gore re latlhegelwe ke matshelo a batho ba le bantsi le go tlisa dikhuduego le tshotlego e e seng kana ka sepe.

eng: since the outbreak of cov id19 in the country, with the nationwide lockdown and the pressure on our health facilities, many hiv , aids and tuberculosis services have suffered.
tsn: fa e sale covid19 e runya ka fa naegeng, mmogo le dikgato tsa go sekega nakwana ditiro tsa ka fa nageng naga ka bophara go tsenyeletsa le kgatelelo mo maokelong a rona, ditirelo di le dintsi tsa kalaﬁ ya hiv , aids le tsa bolwetse jwa lehuba (tb) di gogile boima.

eng: this has posed a challenge for people testing and starting antiretroviral treatment.
tsn: seno se tlhodile matsapa mo bathong gore ba se kgone go dira diteko le go simolola ka melemo ya thibelaketegelo ya kokwanatlhoko ya lebolelateng (arv).

eng: many people found it difficult to collect their medicines and fewer people accessed other services, such as voluntary male medical circumcision.
tsn: batho ba le bantsi ba paletswe ke go lata melemo ya bona mme ba bangwe ba le mmalwanyana fela ba kgonne go bona ditirelo tse dingwe, tse di jaaka go ithaopa go rupisiwa sekgowa ga banna.

eng: at the same time, there are many lessons that have been learnt from our public health response to the coronavirus pandemic that can strengthen our fight against hiv and tb.
tsn: le fa go le jalo, go gontsi go re go ithutileng gone mo dikgatong tseo di tserweng ke maokelo a puso mo go samaganeng le leroborobo la mogare wa corona e leng botlhale jo re ka bo dirisang go samaganang le hiv le tb.

eng: south africa continues to have the largest number of people living with hiv in the world.
tsn: aforika borwa e santse e na le palo e e kwa godimo ya batho ba ba tshelang ka hiv lefatshe ka bophara.

eng: it is encouraging, however, that over the last decade we made progress in reducing the number of new hiv infections in the population by nearly 60%.
tsn: le fa go le jalo, go a rotloetsa gore mo ngwagasomeng yo o fetileng re nnile le kgatelopele mo go fokotseng dipalo tsa dikgetse tse dintšhwa tsa batho ba ba tshwaetsegang mo baaging ka palo e e atumetseng go 60%.

eng: it is also encouraging that hiv infections in adolescent girls and young women have significantly declined in the last decade.
tsn: go a rotloetsa gape le gore ditshwaetso tsa hiv mo barwetsaneng le mo makgarebeng le teng di fokotsegile thata go ne mo ngwagasomeng yo o fetileng.

eng: this is a crucial group because they are much more likely to be at risk of getting hiv .
tsn: setlhopha sa batho bano se botlhokwa thata gonne ke sone gantsi se leng mo kotsing ya go tshwarwa ke hiv .

eng: our treatment programme has contributed to a reduction in the number of deaths due to aids by 60%.
tsn: lenaane la rona la go okobatsa bolwetse jono le nnile mosola thata mo go fokotseng dipalo tsa dintsho tse di tlhodiwang ke aids ka palo e e kanaka 60%.

eng: there has been a greater reduction in hivrelated deaths among young people.
tsn: go nnile le phokotsego e kgolo mo bašweng ba ba tlhokafalang ka ntlha ya hiv .

eng: it was possible to reduce the number of deaths because we, together with our partners, have rolled out an extensive antiretroviral programme reaching millions of people living with the disease.
tsn: go ne go tshwanetse gore re kgone go fokotsa dipalo tsa dintsho ka ntlha ya gore rona, mmogo le badirisanimmogo ba rona, re thankgolotse lenaane le legolo la diarv le le thusang dimilione tsa batho ba naga ya rona ba ba nang le bolwetse jono.

eng: at the beginning of the decade, our programme to prevent mother to child transmission (pmtct) of hiv had very low coverage.
tsn: kwa tshimologong ya ngwagasome ono, lenaane la rona la go thibela bolwetse jono go fetela mo baneng ba ba iseng ba belegwe (pmtct) le ne le thusa palo e nnye ya batho.

eng: now we have one of the highest rates of coverage of pmtct in southern africa, which has substantially reduced rates of infection among children.
tsn: jaanong re na le batho ba le bantsi thata ba re ba thusang ka pmtct mo karolong ya borwa jwa aforika, e leng seo se fokoditseng thata dipalo tsa bana ba ba iseng ba belegwe ba ba tshwaetsegileng.

eng: while we have reduced deaths and new infections, we still are far from reaching the goal we committed ourselves in 2016 of achieving a 75% reduction in hiv infections by 2020. if we succeed in doing so, we are likely to end aids as a public health threat by 2030. unfortunately, we are not there yet.
tsn: le fa re fokoditse dipalo tsa dintsho le tsa ditshwaetsego tse dintšhwa, re santse re le kgakala le go ﬁ tlhelela dipeelo tsa rona tseo re ipeetseng tsona ka ngwaga wa 2016 fa re ne re re re batla go fokotsa sekgala sa ditshwaetso tsa hiv ka 75% fa re tsena mo ngwageng wa 2020. fa re ka atlega mo go direng seno, go na le kgonagalo ya gore mo ngwageng wa 2030 re tla bo re fedisitse aids gore e se tlhole e nna setshosetsi mo boitekanelong jwa setšhaba.

eng: we have to do far more to ensure that young people are empowered to prevent infections, including through changing behaviour, accessing condoms and testing regularly.
tsn: re tshwanetse go dira go tlala seatla go netefatsa gore bašwa ba matlafadiwa gore ba kgone go iphemela gore ba se tshwaetsege, go tsenyeletsa le ka go fetola maitsholo a bona, go neelwa mesomelwana le go dira diteko gangwe le gape.

eng: we need to make sure that everyone who is infected has access to treatment and care.
tsn: re tshwanetse go netefatsa gore motho mongwe le mongwe yo a tshwaetsegileng bolwetse jwa gagwe bo a okobadiwa mme o a tlhokomelwa.

eng: we need to work harder on hiv prevention among key populations, including sex workers, men who have sex with men, and people who inject drugs.
tsn: re tshwaetse go dira ka natla mo go thibeleng hiv mo baaging bao ba leng mo kotsing e e kwa godimo mo setšhabeng, go akaretsa gape le batho ba ba gwebang ka thobalano, banna ba ba robalanang le banna ba bangwe, mmogo le mo bathong ba ba dirisang diritibatsi ka gotlhabana ka lemao le le lengwe.

eng: we must end the stigma and discrimination towards these populations.
tsn: re tshwanetse go fedisa mamodula mmogo le go tlhaola batho bano.

eng: we cannot hope to end hiv if we ignore the needs, concerns and rights of any part of our population.
tsn: ga gona gore re ka solofela go fedisa hiv fa re itlhokomolosa ditlhokwa, matshwenyego le ditshwanelo tsa baagi ba ba rileng ba naga ya rona.

eng: south africa needs to increase efforts to medically circumcise young men to reduce their risk of acquiring hiv .
tsn: aforika borwa e tshwanetse go oketsa matsapa a yona a go rupisiwa sekgowa ga basimanyana go fokotsa dikotsi tsa gore ba ka topa hiv .

eng: unsafe circumcision should not leave young men with lifelong health problems, and no one should die from circumcision.
tsn: go rupisiwa go go sa babalesegang ga go a tshwanela go tlogela makau ka mathata a boitekanelo a go ya go ile, e bile ga go motho yo a tshwanetseng go tlhokafala ka ntlha ya go rupisiwa.

eng: we must make sure that young men have safe circumcision.
tsn: re tshwanetse go netefatsa gore makau a tsenela thobalano e e babalesegileng.

eng: we are encouraged by findings of a recent study on preexposure prophylaxis (prep).
tsn: re rotloeditswe ke dipoelo tse di sa tswang go ribololwa tsa dipatlisiso tsa melemo ya thibelotshwaetso (prep).

eng: unlike antiretroviral treatment that is given to people who are hiv positive, prep involves the regular use of antiretroviral drugs by hiv negative people to prevention infection.
tsn: jaaka yona e dira go farologana le melemo ya arv e e neelwang batho ba ba nang le hiv , prep e nwewa gangwe le gape ke batho ba ba senang hiv go ba thibela gore ba se tshwaetsege.

eng: the study, conducted by scientists from the hiv prevention trials network, found that longacting injections once every eight weeks was better than the daily tablet used for hiv prevention.
tsn: dipatlisiso tseno, tse di dirilweng ke borasaense ba setlamo sa diteko tsa go thibela hiv , di ribotse gore go itlhaba lemao gangwe le gape gangwe mo dibekeng di le robedi go botoka go na le go tsaya melemo letsatsi le lengwe le le lengwe go thibela hiv .

eng: these findings have the potential to significantly strengthen our response to the epidemic.
tsn: diphitlhelelo tseno di na le bokgoni jo bogolo jwa go matlafatsa ka fao re tsibogelang leroborobo leno.

eng: if we are to succeed in ending aids as a public health threat within the next decade, we need to combine these medical breakthroughs with fundamental changes in behaviour.
tsn: fa e le gore re batla go atlega mo go fediseng aids jaaka e le selo se se tshosetsang tirelo ya boitekanelo mo pusong mo sebakeng sa ngwagasome se se latelang, re tshwanetse go dirisa mmogo diphitlhelelo tseno tsa dipatlisiso tsa melemo le maitsholo a mašwa.

eng: we also need to tackle the economic and social conditions that contrib ute to high rates of infection.
tsn: re tlhoka gape go samagana le seemo sa loago le sa ikonomi e leng tse dingwe tsa dilo tse di tlholang ditshwaetso tse dintsi.

eng: one of our central tasks is to empower adolescent girls and young women, educationally, economically and socially.
tsn: e nngwe ya ditiro tsa rona tse di botlhokwa ke go matlafatsa basetsanyana le makgarebe a rona, ka thuto, ka go itirela letseno le ka go ikemela mo loagong.

eng: they need to be able to make their own decisions about every aspect of their lives, including their sexuality and sexual behaviour.
tsn: ba tlhoka go itseela ditshwetso ka bobona ka ga ntlha nngwe le nngwe mo matshelong a bona, go tsenyeletsa le go itlhophela gore ba ratana jang le go itlhophela gore ba diragatsa thobalano ya mofuta o o ntseng jang.

eng: ultimately, we will achieve the end of aids through the empowerment of young people, women and other people at risk.
tsn: kwa bokhutlong re tla kgona go fedisa aids fa fela re matlafatsa bašwa, basadi le batho ba ba leng mo kotsing ya go ka tshwaetsega.

eng: this includes empowerment through access to information, advice and support.
tsn: matlafatso eno e raya gore ba se timiwe tshedimosetso, ba tlhabiwe botlhale le go tshegediwa.

eng: it includes access to education and economic opportunities, especially for young women.
tsn: go raya gore ba tshwanetse go isiwa sekolong le go bulelwa ditšhono tsa go itirela letseno, bogolojang makgarebe a rona.

eng: empowerment also means that every person must have access to testing, treatment and other health services.
tsn: go matlafadiwa gape go tlhalosa gore motho mongwe le mongwe o tshwanetse go diriwa diteko, a okobaletswe bolwetse jwa gagwe mme a neelwe le ditirelo tse dingwe gape tsa boitekanelo.

eng: another chance to get your matric cathy grosvenor it is never too late to get your matric or to achieve the results you want, is the message behind the department of basic edu cation’s (dbe) second chance matric support programme.
tsn: tšhono e nngwe ya go konosetsa dithuto tsa gago tsa materiki cathy grosvenor ga go thari go ka konosetsa dithuto tsa gago tsa materiki kgotsa go iponela dipholo tse o di batlang, ono ke molaetsa go tswa mo letsholong la lefapha la thuto ya motheo (dbe) le le ka ga go tshegetsa baithuti go iponela tšhono e nngwe ya go konosetsa dithuto tsa materiki.

eng: director of the programme, dr sandy malapile, says a matric qualification is an absolute necessity because without it, many doors of opportunity remain closed.
tsn: mokaedi wa letsholo leno, ngaka sandy malapile, a re go iponela materiki ke selo se se botlhokwa thata gonne ntle le ona, ditšhono di le dintsi di tla go feta mo tseleng.

eng: "sector training and education authorities (setas), tasked with upskilling the nation through skills programmes and apprenticeships, also require that candidates have a matric," says dr malapile.
tsn: "bothati jwa lekala la thuto le katiso (seta), jo bo rweleng maikarabelo a go tokafatsa bokgoni jwa baagi ka fa nageng ka go ba tlamela ka matsholo a katisobokgoni le a ditiro tsa diatla, le jone bo tlhoka gore batho ba ba tsenelang matsholo ano ba nne le materiki," ga rialo ngaka malapile.

eng: launched in january 2016, the second chance programme supports anyone – of any age – who wants to achieve or improve a matric qualification, subjectbysubject and on a parttime basis.
tsn: letsholo leno la tšhono e nngwe ya go konosetsa dithuto tsa gago tsa materiki, le le sa bolong go thankgololwa ka ferikgong 2016 le tshegetsa mongwe le mongwe yo a batlang go konosetsa dithuto tsa gagwe tsa materiki kgotsa yo a batlang go tokafatsa dipholo tsa dirutwa tsa gagwe, go sa kgathalesege dingwaga tsa gagwe, mme a batla go tsena sekolo mo matsatsing ao a beilweng.

eng: there are no costs involved.
tsn: ga go le sente yo montsho yo a duelelwang.

eng: people who want to im prove their matric results, whether they wrote matric recently or even decades ago.
tsn: batho ba ba batlang go tlhabolola dipholo tsa dirutwa tsa bona, go sa kgathalesege gore ba kwadile ditlha tlhobo tsa bona tsa materiki sešweng jaana kgotsa ga ba boolo go di kwala dingwaga di le masome tse di fetileng.

eng: dr malapile explains that a person wanting to obtain an engineering qualification, for in stance, might need to im prove their mathematics mark to qualify for the course.
tsn: ngaka malapile o tlhalosa gore motho yo a batlang go iponela makwalothuto a boenjenere, go naya motlhala, a ka tlhoka gore a tlhabolole dipholo tsa gagwe tsa serutwa sa dipalo gore a fitlhelele dipeelo tsa go ithutela serutwa seno.

eng: people who failed matric and want a second chance at passing.
tsn: batho ba ba reteletsweng ke go falola materiki mme ba tlhoka tšhono e nngwe gape ya go kwala gape materiki gore ba falole.

eng: people who left school after passing grade 9 (then standard 7), are 21 or older, and wish to obtain their matric.
tsn: batho ba ba tlogetseng sekolo fa ba sena go falola dithuto tsa bona tsa mophato wa bo 9 (o mo malobeng o neng o bediwa standard 7), ba ba nang le dingwaga di le 21 le go feta, mme ba batla go konosetsa dithuto tsa bona tsa materiki.

eng: how to get startedregister at one of the 75 dis trict education offices across the country or online at this website: www.
tsn: ikwadise kwa go e nngwe ya dikantoro tsa tikologo di le 75 tsa lefapha la thuto ka fa nageng kgotsa ikwadise mo inthaneteng mo webesaeteng ya: www.

eng: eservices.
tsn: eservices.

eng: gov.
tsn: gov.

eng: za.
tsn: za .

eng: registration opened on 1 october and will close in february 2021. learners either study on their own or at one of the 133 second chance centres where facetoface learning takes place afterhours and on weekends.
tsn: paka ya ikwadiso e buletswe ka la bo 1 diphalane 2020 mme e tla tswalelwa ka tlhakole 2021. barutwana ba na le tlhopho ya gore ba ithute ka bobona kgotsa ba ye sekolong kwa tikwatikweng e nngwe ya di le 133 mo ba tla rutiwang mo maitseboeng le mo bokhutlhong jwa beke.

eng: dr malapile says only the top performing teachers in each district are employed at these centres.
tsn: ngaka malapile a re barutabana ba ba dirang tiro e ntle mo di tikologong tse ba rutang mo go tsona ke bona ba thapilweng go ruta mo dikolong tseno.

eng: the centres are not available in every town and village, but are located in areas where the greatest number of people have registered, which means their location could change each year.
tsn: dikolo tseno ga di a gasagana moteropong e nngwe le e nngwe le mo metseng e mengwe le e mengwe, mme di teng mo batho ba ikwadisitseng ka bontsi gone, mme seno se raya gore mafelo a dikolo tseno di fitlhelwang mo go ona a ka fetogafetoga ngwaga o mongwe le o mongwe.

eng: both facetoface learners and learners who study at home have access to a full range of study support services, from lessons broadcast on radio and television at specific times; to downloadable online material; and, for those without access to computers, printers and the inter net−printed study material is sent to them by the dbe.
tsn: mekgwa ka bobedi ya go ithuta ka bowena le ya go ya sekolong e tshegediwa ka botlalo ka ditirelo tsa go ithuta, go tsenyeletsa le ka mananeo a seyalemowa le a thelebišene a a tshamekang ka dinako tse di rileng; ba tshegediwa ka didirisiwa tsa go ithuta tse ba ka kgonang go di daonelouta; mme bao ba senang dikhomphiutha, diprintara le inthanete−lefapha le tla ba romela didirisiwa tsa go ithuta tse di gatisitsweng.

eng: people with a computer but no internet or data, may request a cd with all the study material, which will be mailed to them.
tsn: batho ba ba nang le dikhomphiutha mme ba sena ditirelo tsa inthanete kgotsa ba sena data , ba ka ikuela gore ba romelwe cd e mo go yona go tsentsweng didirisiwa tsotlhe tsa go ithuta, mme e tla romelwa ka poso.

eng: "many adult learners may not have lots of time to devote to their studies.
tsn: "batho ba bagolo bontsi jwa bona ga ba na nako e ntsi mo diatleng tsa bona mo ba kaineelang mo dithutong tsa bona.

eng: luck ily, they may decide how many subjects they want to do a year because they do not have to complete their matric within a set time.
tsn: ka lesego, ba ka tsaya tshwetso ya gore ba batla go dira dirutwana di le kae kwa sekolong mongwageng ka ntlha ya gore ga ba gapeletsege gore ba konosetse dithuto tsa bona mo sebakeng se se rileng.

eng: "once registered, the dbe will help each older learner choose the subjects they want to do and explain which ones are compulsory.
tsn: "gang fa ba sena go ikwadisa, dbe e tla thusa moithuti yo mongwe le yo mongwe yo mogolo go tlhopha dirutwa tse a batlang go di ithutela le go mo tlhalosetsa gore ke dirutwa dife tse ba gapeletsegang go di ithutela.

eng: on qualifying, people who left school after 2008 receive a national senior certificate and those who left school earlier, receive an amended senior certificate.
tsn: fa ba sena go konosetsa dithuto tsa bona, batho ba ba tlogetseng sekolo morago ga 2008 ba tla amogela lekwalo la naga la dithuto tse dikgolwane mme bao ba tlogetseng sekolo pele ga ngwaga oo, ba tla amogela lekwalo la naga la dithuto tse dikgolwane le le tlhabolotsweng.

eng: however, dr malapile says both qualifications carry the same weight and, depending on the subjects taken and marks achieved, can be used to apply to universities and colleges.
tsn: le fa go le jalo, ngaka malapile a re makwalo a thuto ano ka bobedi a lekana mme, go lebilwe dirutwa tse ba di tsereng mmogo le dipholo tse ba di fitlheletseng, ba ka di dirisa go ikwadisa kwa diyunibesiti le kwa dikholejeng.

eng: giving second chancesthe dbe holds community roadshows to encourage people to enrol for the second chance programme.
tsn: go neelana ka tšhono e nngwe ya go konosetsa dithuto tsa materikidbe e diragatsa matsholo a go lemosa baagi ka go rotloetsa batho go ikwadisetsa tšhono e nngwe gape ya go konosetsa dithuto tsa materiki.

eng: tertiary education institutions and setas are invited to provide as much information as possible to interested people.
tsn: ditheo tsa thuto e kgolwane mmogo le seta ba kopiwa go tlamela bao ba nang le kgatlhego ka tshedimosetso e ba nang le yona ka bontsi jo ba ka bo kgonang.

eng: at many of these roadshows, minister angie mot shekga was asked by youth to introduce programmes that could assist young people to be more employable, says dr malapile.
tsn: mo matsholong ano a go bula baagi matlho, bašwa ba le bantsi ba botsoloditse tona angie motshekga gore goreng a sa tsenye tirisong manaane a a ka kgonang go thusa bašwa gore ba thapege, ga rialo ngaka malapile.

eng: in response, the dbe is launching a skills development programme this year that will target about 3.4 million young people who are not in employment, education or training.
tsn: mo go tsibogeleng seno, dbe monongwaga e thankgolola lenaane la go tlhabolola bokgoni le le tla thusang bašwa ba le dimilione di le 3.4 ba ba senang ditiro, ba ba seng mo sekolong kgotsa mo katisong.

eng: courses will range from life skills – covering topics such as how to write a cv and what to do at a job interview; to basic skills courses, such as shoe repair, basic itc and literacy.
tsn: dirutwa tsa lenaane leno di tla tsenyeletsa tsa dithuto tsa botshelo – mo ditlhogo tsa dithuto tseno di tla akaretsang tsa go kwala lekwalo la go batla tiro (cv) le gore o ipaakanyetsa jang kopano ya go batla tiro; go tsenyeletsa le dirutwa tsa bokgoni jo bo botlhokwa, jo bo jaaka go baakanya ditlhako, go dirisa khomphiutha le jwa go ithuta go buisa le go kwala.

eng: did you know?
tsn: va o ne o itse?

eng: a better 2021 for all south africans the first weeks of the year have been difficult for all south africans.
tsn: ngwaga wa 2021 o o botoka go maaforika borwa otlhe dibeke tsa ntlha tsa monongwaga di nnile bokete thata go maaforika borwa otlhe.

eng: vukuzenzele unnamed the coronavirus pandemic has gotten worse, with new infections increasing far faster and far higher than before.
tsn: vukuzenzele unnamed leroborobo la mogare wa corona le etegetse, ka ditshwaetsego tse dintšhwa tse di oketsegang ka bonako le seelo se se fetang sa pele.

eng: hospitals have been under great strain as more people have needed medical attention.
tsn: maaokelo a nnile ka fa tlase ga kgatelelo e kgolo ka ntlha ya fa batho ba bantsi ba ne ba tlhoka tlhokomelo ya kalafi.

eng: while most economic sectors have been able to operate again for several months, it will take some time for the economy to recover and for lost jobs to be restored.
tsn: le fa tota bontsi ba makala a ikonomi bo ne ba kgona go dira gape dikgwedi di le mmalwa, go tla tsaya nako gore ikonomi e boele mannong le gore ditiro tse di latlhegetseng batho di busediwe mannong.

eng: as the new year starts, many families are still feeling the effects of the pandemic on their lives and livelihoods.
tsn: jaaka ngwaga o mošwa o simolola, malapa a mantsi a santse a itemogela ditlamorago tsa leroborobo le mo matshelong a bona le mo ditseleng tseo ba iphedisang ka tsona.

eng: the world is now entering the second year of the coronavirus pandemic.
tsn: ga jaana lefatshe le tsena mo ngwageng wa bobedi wa leroborobo la mogare wa corona.

eng: for south africa, as for most countries around the world, the year 2021 will be extremely challenging.
tsn: mo aforika borwa, fela jaaka dinaga di le dintsi go ralala lefatshe, 2021 e tla nna ngwaga o o bokete tota.

eng: the second wave of covid19 infections may well be followed by further waves, which will threaten both the health of our people and the recovery of our economy.
tsn: lekhubu la bobedi la ditshwaetso tsa covid19 le ka latelwa ke makhubu a mangwe gape, a a tla nnang matshosetsi mo boitekanelong jwa batho ba rona gammogo le mo tsosolosong ya ikonomi.

eng: difficult as this year will be, i am certain that we will overcome the pandemic and set our country firmly on the path to recovery.
tsn: le fa tota ngwaga o o tla nna bokete, ke na le bonnete jwa gore re tla fenya leroborobo le, le go tlhoma naga ya rona mo tseleng ya tsosoloso.

eng: my confidence comes from the south african people.
tsn: ke na le tshepo e e tletseng mo bathong ba aforika borwa.

eng: if i look at how south africans responded to this crisis from the moment the virus arrived on our shores, i have no doubt that we have the resilience, discipline and ability to defeat this disease.
tsn: fa ke leba ka moo maaforika borwa a tsibogetseng bothata jo, go simolola ka nako ya fa mogare o o goroga mo nageng ya rona, ga ke na pelaelo ya gore re na le tlhotlheletsego, tlhomamo le bokgoni jwa go fenya bolwetse jo.

eng: certainly there were exceptions, but the vast majority of south africans understood the need for restrictions on their movement and activities, and complied with the regulations that we had to put in place.
tsn: ke nnete gore go nnile le matlhaodi, fela bontsi jwa maaforika borwa bo ne bo tlhaloganya tlhokego ya dikiletso mo motsamaong le mo ditirong tsa bona, mme ba ikobela melawana e re neng ra tshwanelwa ke go e tlhoma.

eng: even more important than compliance, most south africans took responsibility for themselves and for others, following advice on issues like social distancing, wearing a mask and hand washing.
tsn: tota se se nnileng botlhokwa go feta go ikobela melawana ka gore, maaforika borwa a ne a rwala maikarabelo ka bobona le boemong jwa ba bangwe, morago ga maele a a jaaka gore ba se atamelane, ba apare dimmaseke le go tlhapa diatla.

eng: and where we fell short, we have, sadly, seen the consequences.
tsn: kwa re tlhaetseng teng, ka bomadimabe, re ne ra bona ditlamorago.

eng: we now know about the risks of closed spaces and crowded gatherings, of not wearing masks and not keeping our distance from others.
tsn: ga jaana re itse ka ga dikotsi tsa mafelo a a sa tsenelweng ke mowa le dikokoano mo batho e leng ba bantsi mo go tsona, dikotsi tsa go se apare mmaseke le go se katologane ka tolamo le ba bangwe.

eng: we now know much more about the disease and how to prevent its spread.
tsn: ga jaana re itse go le gontsi ka ga bolwetse jo le gore re ka thibela jang kanamo ya bona.

eng: and despite what one could call ‘pandemic fatigue’, we are no less determined as south africans to do what needs to be done.
tsn: mme le fa tota go na le se se ka bidiwang 'letsapa la leroborobo', seno ga se kae gore re le maaforika borwa ga re na maikemisetso a go dira tse di tshwanetseng go dirwa.

eng: as we adhere even more rigorously to the basic prevention measures, we will also be rolling out a mass vaccination campaign.
tsn: jaaka re ikobela mekgwathibelo ya motheo go gaisa pele, re tla bo re thankgolola letsholo le legolo la meento.

eng: as more and more people are vaccinated, we will both save lives and progressively reduce the risk of infection across the population.
tsn: fa batho ba bantsi ba ka entiwa, re tla kgona go boloka matshelo le go tswelela go fokotsa seelo sa tshwaetso go ralala naga.

eng: getting enough vaccines as quickly as possible – and making sure that they reach the people who need them – will be one of the biggest tasks of the year.
tsn: go bona meento e e lekaneng ka bonako le go netefatsa gore e fitlhelela batho ba ba e tlhokang e tla nna nngwe ya ditirokgolo tsa monongwaga.

eng: this will be particularly challenging as every country in the world is clamouring to secure a limited supply of vaccines.
tsn: se e tla nna kgwetlho gonne naga nngwe le nngwe mo lefatsheng e lwela go fitlhelela palo e e rileng ya meento.

eng: but we are hard at work with partners in business, labour and civil society to make this happen.
tsn: fela re semeletse mmogo le balekane ba rona ba kgwebo, mekgatlo ya badiri le baagi go netefatsa gore se se a diragala.

eng: we are working on several fronts to get vaccines, including through the global covax facility, the african union initiative and through our own engagements with vaccine manufacturers.
tsn: re dira mo maphateng a a farologang go bona meento e, go akaretsa setheo sa boditšhaba sa covax, letsholo la dinagatshwaraganelo tsa aforika gammogo le ditherisano tsa rona le batlhagisi ba meento e. jaaka re dira mmogo go fenya leroborobo le, re tla tlhoka go dira mmogo go aga sešwa ikonomi ya rona le go e tlhabolola.

eng: as we act together to overcome the pandemic, we will need to work together to rebuild and transform our economy.
tsn: re na le bokgoni le maikemisetso a go tsosolosa tsamaiso ya ikonomi, go godisa ikonomi ya rona le go tlhola ditiro.

eng: public finances are under extreme strain, now even more so because of the cost of our health response to covid19 and the social and economic relief measures we put in place to assist businesses and poor households.
tsn: matlole a bosetšhaba a ka fa tlase ga kgatelelo e kgolo, segolo ga jaana ka ntlha ya tsibogo ya rona ya boitekanelo kgatlhanong le covid19 gammogo le ditsereganyo tsa kimololo ya loago le ikonomi tse re di dirileng go thusa dikgwebo le malapa a a humanegileng.

eng: the contraction of the economy also meant that tax revenue has declined significantly.
tsn: kwelotlase ya ikonomi e kaya gore le lotseno lwa lekgetho le lona lo ile tlase thata.

eng: there are some parts of the economy that will take longer to recover due to lower global demand generally and restrictions on international travel.
tsn: go dikarolo dingwe tsa ikonomi tse di tla tsayang sebaka go boela mannong ka ntlha ya kwelotlase ya tlhokego ya ditlhagisiwa tsa bona go ralala lefatshe ka kakaretso, gammogo le ka ntlha ya dikiletso mo maetong a boditšhaba.

eng: that is why we need to be innovative and focused in our plans to rebuild the economy.
tsn: ke ka moo re tlhokang go nna manontlhotlho le go tsepama mo maanong a rona a go bopa ikonomi ya rona sešwa.

eng: significantly, the economic reconstruction and recovery plan that we announced in october last year is based on broad consensus among all social part ners on the actions needed to rebuild the economy.
tsn: sa botlhokwa, leano la poposešwa le tsosoloso ya ikonomi le le neng la itsisiwe mo kgweding ya diphalane ngogola le ikaegile ka tumalano e e anameng magareng ga balekane ba loago ka ga dikgato tse di tlhokang go tsewa go tsosolosa ikonomi.

eng: this lays a firm basis for effective cooperation that draws on the resources, capabilities and energies of all sections of society.
tsn: se se tlhoma motheo o o tsepameng wa tirisanommogo e e nang le maungo, e e ikaegileng ka metswedithuso, bokgoni le maatla a maphata otlhe a setšhaba.

eng: we are seeing this in various practical ways.
tsn: re bona se ka ditsela tse di farologaneng tse di diregang.

eng: for example, we have been working closely with private funders and multilateral development institutions to prepare infrastructure projects in areas like transport, human settlements, water and telecommunications.
tsn: sekao, re ntse re dirisana mmogo le batlamedi ba matlole ba makala a poraefete le ditheo tsa tlhabololo ya maphatamantsi go baakanyetsa diporojeke tsa mafaratlhatlha mo makaleng a a jaaka dipalangwa, mafelobonno a batho, metsi le mafaratlhatlha a ditlhaeletsano.

eng: using the infrastructure fund as one of the vehicles, we are developing funding models for these projects that draw on several sources in both the public and private sectors.
tsn: go dirisa letlole la mafaratlhatlha jaaka sengwe sa dikgontshi, re tlhola ditsela tsa kabomatlotlo ya diporojeke tse di nang le metswedi e e farologaneng mo lekaleng la puso le la poraefete.

eng: this is particularly important at a time when public finances are limited.
tsn: se, se botlhokwa thata segolo jaaka matlole a puso a tlhaela.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus is another example of partnership in action.
tsn: lenaneo la ga moporesitente la tsosoloso ya ditiro ke sekao se sengwe sa semphato se se dirang.
